author: By Jesse McKinley and Christina Goldbaum
title: What Schumer’s Rise to Senate Majority Leader Means for New York
description: Senator Chuck Schumer is poised to become the state’s first Senate majority leader, putting New York in position to reap the benefits.
content: There has never been a Senate majority leader from New York, let alone one from Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: America in 2021: Racial Progress in the South, a White Mob in the Capitol
description: A jarring juxtaposition is forcing a 244-year-old nation to contend with its original conundrum: Whose democracy is it?
content: ATLANTA — The day after Georgia elected a Black descendant of sharecroppers and a young Jewish filmmaker to be U.S. senators, underscoring the rising political power of racial and religious minorities, the forces of white grievance politics struck back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink
title: In Amsterdam, Getting High at Coffee Shops May Soon Be for Locals Only
description: The Dutch city, in an effort to crack down on growing numbers of low-budget “drug tourists” and organized crime, plans to forbid the sale of marijuana to foreigners in its famed coffee shops.
content: Tourists hoping to light up a joint in one of Amsterdam’s famed coffee shops after the coronavirus pandemic passes are likely to be disappointed. Soon, all coffee shops in the capital of the Netherlands may no longer be allowed to sell marijuana to foreign customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman
title: Ronna McDaniel is re-elected to lead the Republican National Committee.
description: President Trump’s handpicked chairwoman was unanimously re-elected to lead the Republican National Committee on Friday, as committee members ignored his role in inciting supporters who overtook the Capitol this week to affirm his role atop the party.
content: President Trump’s handpicked chairwoman was unanimously re-elected to lead the Republican National Committee on Friday, as committee members ignored his role in inciting supporters who overtook the Capitol this week to affirm his role atop the party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Dr. Marcella Nunez-Smith Takes Aim at Racial Gaps in Health Care
description: Appointed head of the incoming administration’s task force on health equity, the Yale University scientist “is not sitting in her ivory tower.”
content: Growing up in the United States Virgin Islands, Dr. Marcella Nunez-Smith saw firsthand what can happen in a community with limited access to health care. Her father, Moleto “Bishop” Smith Sr., was only in his 40s when he suffered a debilitating stroke that left him partly paralyzed and with slurred speech.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson and Christopher Buckley
title: Chinese Solar Companies Tied to Use of Forced Labor
description: A new report shows some of the world’s biggest solar companies work with the Chinese government to absorb workers from Xinjiang, programs that are often seen as a red flag for forced labor.
content: In a flat, arid expanse of China’s far west Xinjiang region, a solar technology company welcomed laborers from a rural area 650 miles away, preparing to put them to work at GCL-Poly, the world’s second-largest maker of polysilicon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: We’ve Seen the Ugly Truth About America
description: But if the Democrats dare to use their power, a brave new world might be possible.
content: There are two images. In one, National Guard troops, most with no identifying information on their uniforms, stand on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial in anticipation of violence from people peacefully protesting the killing of George Floyd. In the second image, thousands of protesters — domestic terrorists, really — swarm the Capitol. They wear red MAGA hats and carry Trump flags and show their faces because they want to be seen. They don’t seem to fear the consequences of being identified. More images — a man sitting in Nancy Pelosi’s office, his feet on a desk, a smirk on his face. A man carrying a stolen lectern, smiling at the camera. A man in the Senate chamber doing parkour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Labor force participation is stagnating, and some workers may never come back.
description: The share of Americans who are either working or looking for jobs remains well below pre-pandemic levels, data released Friday showed, a sign that many working-age adults have been pushed onto the labor market’s sidelines as the health crisis persists.
content: The share of Americans who are either working or looking for jobs remains well below pre-pandemic levels, data released Friday showed, a sign that many working-age adults have been pushed onto the labor market’s sidelines as the health crisis persists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: This Couple Had a Hurried Ceremony — and Then Brain Surgery
description: Shane Gerdes was told he had a tumor. While in the hospital, he called his long-term partner, Darien Monk, and asked her if she’d like to have a wedding. Now.
content: Darien Monk doesn’t wish a broken espresso machine on anybody, but once upon a time she wouldn’t have minded if the ones at the Coffee & Tea Exchange in Chicago, where she works, were out of order a little more often.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sullivan
title: Forget About a Gym. These People Pay Thousands for Personalized Workouts.
description: “I’m in for $31,000 a year,” a fashion consultant says. That covers a trainer, a nutritionist, an age management doctor and “tons of supplements.”
content: In years past, a new gym membership at the start of a year was as predictable as a glass of champagne at midnight. But this is not a usual year, with a quarter of the health clubs in the country estimated to have closed in 2020, and a far larger percentage of clubs operating with limited capacity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: Before They Wed, They Dated in Bahia, Dublin, Bangkok, Cape Town and Tulum
description: Renate Hartman and Melinda Michels met four years ago at a conference in Brazil, and maintained a relationship while living thousands of miles apart.
content: In September 2016, Renate Hartman attended the Association for Women’s Rights in Development International Forum conference in Bahia, Brazil. Also called “Feminist Futures,” it drew 2,000 people from around the world working for women’s and L.G.B.T.Q. rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Freeman Gill
title: Preserving New York’s Ties to the Underground Railroad
description: Safe houses and other structures used in the fight against slavery were often clandestine, and survivors today can be difficult to document. But there’s a 19th-century house in Washington Heights …
content: Are landmarks that celebrate Black history given proper consideration by city government? That is a question hovering over two threatened antebellum houses once owned by abolitionists, one in Brooklyn and one in Manhattan, that have come before the Landmarks Preservation Commission in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: These Grooms Bonded Over Faith and Football
description: Christopher Hanson and William Hoffman’s first date was at a Washington beer garden. But they really got to know each other among bleachers and pews.
content: One Monday in 2014, Christopher Justin Hanson sat down for a job interview at the headquarters of Covington & Burling, a law firm in Washington. As the interviewer, who was stationed in front of windows overlooking Pennsylvania Avenue, thumbed through Mr. Hanson’s résumé, he noticed that Mr. Hanson didn’t have any experience in Washington. Mr. Hanson lived in Wisconsin at the time. Why, the interviewer asked, did Mr. Hanson want to start practicing in Washington?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Zach Montague
title: In a new video, Trump addresses violence at the Capitol and says ‘a new administration’ will be sworn in.
description: President Trump came the closest he has so far to a concession statement on Thursday in a videotaped address from the White House, a day after he had helped steer his supporters toward the Capitol, where they rioted and took over the building.
content: President Trump came the closest he has so far to a concession statement on Thursday in a videotaped address from the White House, a day after he had helped steer his supporters toward the Capitol, where they rioted and took over the building.

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Pfizer Says Its Vaccine Works Against Key Mutation in Contagious Variants
description: It’s good news, but experts cautioned that the new variants from Britain and South Africa also carry other potentially dangerous mutations that have not yet been investigated.
content: Pfizer and BioNTech announced on Friday that their Covid vaccine is effective against one of the mutations present in the new contagious variants identified in Britain and South Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Late Night Is Unimpressed by Titanic-Fleeing Republicans
description: “Resigning with two weeks left feels less like some moral stand and more like leaving early to beat traffic,” Jimmy Fallon said of the departing officials.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: Marvel’s Latest Frontier? In ‘WandaVision,’ It’s the Suburbs
description: Marvel’s first series for Disney+ is part drama, part homage to vintage sitcoms, following the misfit heroes played by Elizabeth Olsen and Paul Bettany to some weird places.
content: In the time they have spent playing Marvel heroes together, Elizabeth Olsen and Paul Bettany have gotten extremely comfortable with each other. Not even a little misdirected mucus during the making of their new Disney+ series, “WandaVision” — an incident they affectionately describe as “Snotgate” — flustered them for long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: The Attraction Was Real. The Legislature Wasn’t.
description: Olivia Barket and Cory Yeffet met at a high school debate tournament. They kept meeting.
content: At around 5 a.m. one day in the fall of 2016, Olivia Alexandra Barket received an unexpected knock on the door of her Brooklyn apartment.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Dreamiest Ricotta Gnocchi
description: Mark Bittman’s recipe is tender and perfect, served with browned butter, fresh basil and burst cherry tomatoes.
content: Hi, friends, and welcome to Five Weeknight Dishes. Margaux Laskey filling in for Em today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen L. Cox
title: What Trump Shares With the ‘Lost Cause’ of the Confederacy
description: It is hard to miss the parallels between now and then of rewriting history and campaigns of disinformation.
content: Wednesday morning, President Trump urged a crowd of supporters who showed up in Washington, D.C., to “walk down to the Capitol” and protest the certification of the election taking place nearby on Pennsylvania Avenue. A few hours later, he stood in the White House Rose Garden to deliver a different message after members of this same group — who carried flags bearing his name — stormed the Capitol, brawled with Capitol Police and breached both chambers of Congress. Mr. Trump repeated false claims about election fraud but told them: “You have to go home now. We have to have peace.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
title: The White House slips deeper into crisis in the final days of the Trump presidency.
description: What was already shaping up as a volatile final stretch to the Trump presidency took on an air of national emergency as the White House emptied out and some Republicans joined Speaker Nancy Pelosi and a cascade of Democrats calling for Mr. Trump to be removed from office without waiting the 13 days until the inauguration of President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.

title: How the Head of a Vaccine Research Clinic Spends Her Sundays
description: Dr. Stephanie Sterling, an infectious disease expert, treats patients and oversees vaccination efforts and trials.
content: As vaccination efforts ramp up around the city, Dr. Stephanie Sterling is well aware of the challenges ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: They Met in a Car Pool, Now They’re Married
description: Kayla McCulley and Matthew Spencer briefly met in a car pool, then several months later reconnected on Tinder. They quickly bonded over books.
content: In the early days of their relationship, Kayla McCulley and Matthew Spencer created a book club — for two.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reddit bans forum dedicated to supporting Trump, and Twitter permanently suspends his allies who spread conspiracy theories.
description: The social news and message board site Reddit banned a forum dedicated to discussing and promoting President Trump from its site on Friday, and Twitter permanently suspended Mr. Trump’s account and those of several prominent supporters who used the platform to spread conspiracy theories, the latest moves of major technology platforms to diminish Mr. Trump digitally after his supporters staged an assault on the U.S. Capitol on Wednesday.

title: Hispanic unemployment shot up in the latest report.
description: Unemployment rates for Hispanic workers shot up in December, even as the jobless rate moderated for Black workers and held roughly steady for whites, showing that the costs of recent job losses were being felt unevenly across demographic groups.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: 6 Months After Leaving the Hospital, Covid Survivors Still Face Lingering Health Issues
description: A large study of patients from a Wuhan, China hospital showed that a half-year later, three-quarters were struggling with problems like fatigue, depression and diminished lung function.
content: For millions of coronavirus survivors, it’s an increasingly important question: How common, how serious and how long-lasting are the physical and mental aftereffects of Covid-19?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Wall
title: The Road to This Wedding Was Paved With Theft, Lies, Tears, Other Marriages — and Forgiveness
description: Hal Karp, who overcame drug and alcohol addiction, asked forgiveness for the pain he had caused, decades ago, to Irene Sibaja. His vulnerability led to a reconnection.
content: The lessons from the love story of Irene Sibaja and Hal Karp are many, but here are some of the more obvious: The old dating adage “right person, wrong time” is real; forgiveness is a gift; sharing your darkest moments can have a positive outcome; and looking for an ex online can sometimes be a good idea.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Republicans splinter over whether to make a full break from Trump.
description: President Trump not only inspired a mob to storm the Capitol on Wednesday — he also brought the Republican Party close to a breaking point.
content: President Trump not only inspired a mob to storm the Capitol on Wednesday — he also brought the Republican Party close to a breaking point.

author: By Ted Widmer
title: The Capitol Takeover That Wasn’t
description: In 1861, a pro-Southern mob wanted to block the tallying of electoral votes for Lincoln. So did some congressmen.
content: In the confusion that followed Wednesday’s desecration of the Capitol, it was widely reported that the last time the building was stormed was in 1814. That overlooked a desperate day in 1861, nearly as lethal to democracy. On Feb. 13, a mob gathered outside the Capitol and tried to force its way in to disrupt the counting of the electoral certificates that would confirm Abraham Lincoln’s election three months earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Side Hustles and Handouts: A Tough Year Ahead for U.K. Theater Workers
description: With playhouses closed for the next few months, actors and backstage crews are looking for new ways to make ends meet.
content: LONDON — Last August, Tom Boucher was among the first in Britain’s theater industry to get back to work, after theaters were closed for months because of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Small-Business Loan Program Will Restart Monday, but Not for All
description: A small group of lenders that focus on underserved borrowers will get priority when the Paycheck Protection Program resumes.
content: Lenders who specialize in working with Black- and minority-owned small businesses will have a head start in tapping Paycheck Protection Program funds when the program reopens next week, a move meant to address complaints that the aid was not distributed equitably the last time around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: A Capitol Police officer dies from injuries sustained during the pro-Trump rampage.
description: Officer Brian D. Sicknick died Thursday night. Officials said he was “injured while physically engaging with protesters.”
content: A United States Capitol Police officer died Thursday night from injuries sustained when he engaged with a pro-Trump mob that descended on the U.S. Capitol the day before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabrielle Giffords
title: Gabby Giffords: 10 Years Ago, a Gunman Tried to Silence Me
description: During a week in which our country has endured shock, I’ve thought a lot about resilience and determination.
content: Ten years ago today I went to meet with my constituents in front of a grocery store in Tucson, Ariz. I was a young congresswoman, just sworn in for a third term; it had been a long and hard campaign in a charged national environment. Soon after I arrived that morning, a gunman opened fire. He shot me in the head at close range. Eighteen other people were shot that morning. Six died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Cuomo Widens Eligibility After Vaccine Goes Unused or Is Even Thrown Out
description: Three million more people will be permitted to schedule vaccinations, including those 75 and older, as the campaign in New York gets off to a dispiriting start.
content: Under increasing pressure to relieve a backlog of hundreds of thousands of unused coronavirus vaccine doses, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Friday expanded the eligibility groups to include three million more people, including those 75 and older.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The Biden administration said it would release nearly all available doses later this month.
content: Weeks into the American vaccination effort and the country is terribly behind schedule. Of the roughly 21.5 million doses that have been distributed, only about six million have been injected into the arms of Americans, according to data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marilyn Stasio
title: Murder, Murder Everywhere: the Woods, the Hospital, the Market Square
description: Marilyn Stasio surveys the latest crime novels and finds them very much to her liking.
content: Bill Smith and Lydia Chin, sleuthing partners in a series of smart, sophisticated mysteries by S. J. Rozan, find themselves working for a most unusual client in THE ART OF VIOLENCE (Pegasus Crime, 275 pp., $25.95). Sam Tabor, a painter and a convicted murderer to boot, owes his early prison release to influential members of the art scene. “They see the violence in the work, they think it’s also in him, and they adore it,” the artist’s brother says. But while his supporters are convinced of his innocence (or willing to overlook his guilt for the sake of his edgy art), Sam suspects that he may indeed be murdering women while he’s in a fugue state. “I get stressed, I get drunk, I kill women. Is that so hard to understand?” Can Bill and Lydia confirm Sam’s fears before more people die?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and David Enrich
title: Deutsche Bank Will Pay $125 Million Over Bribery Violations
description: The German lender will enter a deferred prosecution agreement to resolve charges stemming from its attempts to win business in several countries.
content: For nearly seven years it seemed like a good way to drum up business for Deutsche Bank: pay millions of dollars to consultants in countries like Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Italy and China.

title: Trump Administration Politicized Some Intelligence on Foreign Election Influence, Report Finds
description: A report to lawmakers from a watchdog in the Office of the Director of National Intelligence criticizes how threat intelligence was analyzed and presented.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration politicized the intelligence around foreign election interference in 2020, resulting in significant errors in its reports last year to Congress and the public, a report by the intelligence community ombudsman concluded.

title: The man who stormed Pelosi’s office and a West Virginia lawmaker are among those arrested.
description: A lawmaker from West Virginia and a man who broke into Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office and posed at her desk were among those arrested on charges related to the siege at the Capitol, federal law enforcement officials announced on Friday as they promised an exhaustive investigation into the violence.

title: The I.R.S. is trying to redirect millions of stimulus payments that went to unused accounts.
description: If you’re anticipating a stimulus payment that hasn’t yet landed, continue to monitor your bank accounts — and your snail mail.
content: The Internal Revenue Service misdirected stimulus payments for an estimated 13 million accounts, but the agency on Friday said it is trying to redirect to the money to the proper place. If you’re anticipating a stimulus payment that hasn’t yet landed, continue to monitor your bank accounts — and your snail mail.

author: By Sarah Twombly
title: Juggling My Children, Their Alcoholic Sitter and My Own Sobriety
description: The babysitter says she has nine days sober, but we all lie, every addict, every alcoholic.
content: Tonight I left my children with our longtime babysitter, who claims she is nine days sober, but is possibly drunk or high.

author: By Campbell Robertson and Miriam Jordan
title: For Immigrants Watching a Mob Storm the Capitol, a Sense of Shock and Shame
description: After years of seeing the U.S. as a beacon of democracy, many new Americans found themselves asking: Had their new country fallen this low? Or was this what it was all along?
content: A little more than five years ago, Ahmad Shah Srosh was standing alongside the U.S. soldiers who had come to his country, helping them promote democracy to his fellow Afghans. He was called an “infidel” for this work; his brother was murdered because of it. But Mr. Shrosh saw in the United States an example of the rewards that awaited when true democracy took root.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Protesters Given Prison Terms for Beating Reporter at Hong Kong Airport
description: The sentences, stemming from an attack on a journalist for China’s state news media, were the heaviest yet in connection with the 2019 protests, a lawyer said.
content: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong court on Friday sentenced two men and one woman to several years in prison for assaulting a Chinese state media reporter during a protest that paralyzed the territory’s international airport in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Deplatforming of President Trump
description: He is running out of places to post.
content: As President Trump belatedly conceded defeat in the 2020 election — after lawmakers and, reportedly, his own cabinet members weighed how to remove him from office — he has found himself with ever-fewer avenues to speak out online, underscoring the power of internet giants and an abrupt shift in how they treat his behavior online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Tommy Lasorda, a Dodger From His Cleats to His Cap, Dies at 93
description: “Cut my veins, and I bleed Dodger blue,” said Lasorda, who managed the club to two World Series championships in a decades-long Hall of Fame career.
content: Tommy Lasorda, the irrepressible baseball lifer who managed the Los Angeles Dodgers to four National League pennants and two World Series championships in a Hall of Fame career that spanned eight decades of bleeding Dodger blue, died on Thursday in Fullerton, Calif. He was 93 and had been the oldest living member of the Baseball Hall of Fame.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Wortham
title: As an Intense Winter Unfolds, Some Lessons From Herbalists
description: You and plants, together during a fearsomely uncertain time.
content: Humans have relied on plants for their healing properties as long as we’ve been incarnated on this planet. Sumerian clay tablets from ancient Mesopotamia contained instructions for the herbal preparation of more than 200 different plants, including poppy and mandrake. A Neanderthal burial site discovered in the 1960s contained branches of a bush known to contain ephedrine, commonly used to treat breathing ailments, and several wildflowers that also have medicinal properties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: David Perdue concedes to Jon Ossoff in Georgia.

content: Three days after the runoff elections in Georgia that secured full congressional control for Democrats, Senator David Perdue acknowledged his loss to his Democratic challenger, Jon Ossoff.

content: The coronavirus pandemic has felled another Broadway show: “Mean Girls.”

title: Congresswoman Apologizes for Making an Approving Reference to Hitler
description: Representative Mary Miller, an Illinois Republican, had faced condemnation and calls to resign for declaring at a rally: “Hitler was right on one thing: He said, ‘Whoever has the youth, has the future.’”
content: A freshman member of the House of Representatives said on Friday that she regretted having made an approving reference to Hitler at a rally in Washington — a comment that drew condemnation from members of both parties and prompted some Democrats to demand that she resign.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beverly Gage and Emily Bazelon
title: How to Ensure This Never Happens Again
description: The election and its aftermath have revealed weaknesses in our democracy. Here’s how we can fix some of them.
content: The path from the Nov. 3 election has been harrowing for American democracy. Though state and local officials ran clean, well-functioning elections, leaving no doubt that Joe Biden was the victor, President Trump and a sizable faction of Republicans in Congress have relentlessly tried to subvert the results. Their assault culminated in Wednesday’s insurrection at the Capitol, a physical attack on the home of our democracy, incited by the sitting president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
title: K-12: The Spring Semester to Come
description: Re-opening debates rage, teachers wait for vaccines and remote learning struggles continue.
content: “We’ll be covering the on-again, off-again efforts of districts to restart or expand in-person instruction,” said James Dao, a national editor overseeing education coverage at The Times. “What will it take to make teachers and students feel safe? What role will the Biden administration play in making that happen?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Vaccine Demand Has Health Officials Turning to Eventbrite
description: Public health officials are using Eventbrite’s online ticketing platform to schedule shots. But appointments are still hard to find, and not everyone knows how to use the website.
content: In the early stages of a global push to distribute the coronavirus vaccine to those who need it most — a process that has, so far, managed to be both hectic and slow — some health officials have turned to an unexpected tool: the ticketing website Eventbrite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: When Disaster Hits Home for a Global Aid Organization
description: Raj Shah, the head of the Rockefeller Foundation, spent a career working on disaster response in the developing world. The coronavirus pandemic has put his focus on the U.S.
content: Not long before the pandemic hit, Raj Shah, the president of the Rockefeller Foundation, was in a rural town in India to inspect a new solar-powered micro-grid funded by the foundation. At dusk, the government’s unreliable power system faltered, plunging the town into darkness. Moments later, the lights came back on, this time powered by the micro-grid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Nicki Minaj Pays Tracy Chapman $450,000 in Copyright Dispute
description: The singer and songwriter sued after an unreleased Minaj song, which borrowed heavily from Chapman’s “Baby Can I Hold You,” was played on a radio show.
content: For months, the entertainment industry’s legal calendar had an intriguing item on the horizon: a copyright trial pitting Tracy Chapman, the revered and reclusive singer-songwriter, against the firebrand rapper Nicki Minaj.
source.name: The New York Times
